message.raw:
Added auto_scroll_to_end module, with its method set_auto_scroll_to_end

This is a function that takes a scrollbar as an argument, and configures it
to be kept scrolled to the end whenever the range of the scrollbar increases,
but only if it was already scrolled to the end before the range was increased.

This is useful for text output and adding items to a list.

Modified OutputBox to use this instead of duplicating code.

Bumped patch version number.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug in outputbox: messages sent by threads soon to end sometimes were
not sent. This was because the sockets in that thread would be garbage collected
and had linger disabled. Linger is now enabled so sockets will not be destroyed
until their messages are sent.

Also streamlined the receiving code a little - check in advance how many messages
rather than relying on try except. This is related to me currently investigating
a certain kind of exception that gets raised in certain circumstances, that
I'm trying to avoid best I can.

message.raw:
Fixed as far as I know all corner cases for the outputbox.

It is up to callers to provide a newline character or not - outputbox will not
add one in. It should faithfully reproduce what it is sent, with unicode, colour
for stderr, and removing lines after it has more than 1000 (settable at
instantiation). The remaining scrolling issues seem fixed once and for all,
and there should be an appropriate font on every platform.

message.raw:
outputbox now does not insert its own newlines after outputting. Calling code
should so this itself. This is important because outputbox should be able to
receive streamed stderr and stdout from processes, which will not necessarily
be line buffered. And even if it is, this means doubling up on newline characters.

message.raw:
Added PySide support. Moved build process to release-time rather than install-time.
Users may install from pip or easy_install without having PySide or PyQt4 installed.
However if they want to build from a mercurial clone alone, they will need to
have PySide and pyside-rcc, and/or PyQt4 and pyrcc4, whicher they want to use
support for either can be enabled and disabled via boolean flags at the top
of setup.py.

Bumped version to 1.4.0

message.raw:
Added the Fugue icon set, which is CC licensed and free to use with attribution.
Importing qtutils.icons will build the required resource file icons.qrc and python
resource module _icons.py. The latter is then automatically imported, adding the
resources to any Qt application code importing this module. This code
assumes PyQt4 and will not work with PySide.

To use for development:

import qtutils.icons once, from anywhere, to do the build process.

Point Qt Designer to <qtutils directory>/icons/icons.qrc. You will then be able
to select icons from within Qt Designer.

From your application, import qtutils.icons before loading the GUI. This will
register the resources with PyQt4 by importing the autogenerated _icons.py.

I still need to sort out distribution issues - need to do the build at install
time rather than runtime, and ensure devs have access to the .qrc file, which
Qt Designer won't be able to see if it is stuck inside an .egg file. Eggs are
going the way of the dinosaur though, so perhaps this won't be a problem.
Installing from pip should be fine. I will investigate.

* Generalised the UiLoader class to provide a common interface for loading ui files for both PyQt and PySide

message.raw:
reverted invoke_in_main to the version in changeset:b1dd4a1a1c45

Not sure why, but the most recent version seems to result in programs randomly segfaulting.
The version committed here leaks memory (very slowly) due to a PySide bug (see https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/PYSIDE-205 ) but at least it doesn't segfault.

message.raw:
Improved invoke_in_main to *not* require my special QThread

inmain/inmain_later now pass the function to be run to a QThread over a Queue. This QThread posts the event back to the main thread using the inbuilt signal mechanism that do not leak memory.

This now implemets identical functionality to changeset:b1dd4a1a1c45 without the memory leak caused by postEvent

message.raw:
Fixed many bugs in dragdroptab (perhaps oneday I'll rewrite it with the knowledge I've gained in the last 11 months!)

* Fixed issue where setting the current index (during tab focus restore) was not actually causing the tab to become active
* Switched some event processing to use QCoreApplication.postEvent rather than just calling the function directly
* Fixed the mimeData for our drag event to be custom, so that you can't drag a device tab into the hostname text box of the camera tab (for example)
* Fixed a bug where dragging a device tab (that was the sole tab in a notebook) to another notebook, and back again, would cause the tab to disappear (self.havent_left_source_tab code was being incorrectly reset, and other code was only running if it was False)
* Fixed an issue with incorrect tab label being highlighted (or no tab being highlighted at all)
* Stopped the flickering of the tab label when re-ordering the tab after moving to another notebook.
* Fixed an issue where we weren't re-adding the tab to it's original location if it didn't have a parent notebook unless the drag/drop was rejected by the target. It now doesn't matter if the drag was accepted or rejected by the target, if the dragged tab is in no-mans-land, it should go back to where it started from (hopefully!)

values.message:
Fixed many bugs in dragdroptab (perhaps oneday I'll rewrite it with the knowledge I've gained in the last 11 months!)

* Fixed issue where setting the current index (during tab focus restore) was not actually causing the tab to become active
* Switched some event processing to use QCoreApplication.postEvent rather than just calling the function directly
* Fixed the mimeData for our drag event to be custom, so that you can't drag a device tab into the hostname text box of the camera tab (for example)
* Fixed a bug where dragging a device tab (that was the sole tab in a notebook) to another notebook, and back again, would cause the tab to disappear (self.havent_left_source_tab code was being incorrectly reset, and other code was only running if it was False)

* Stopped the flickering of the tab label when re-ordering the tab after moving to another notebook.
* Fixed an issue where we weren't re-adding the tab to it's original location if it didn't have a parent notebook unless the drag/drop was rejected by the target. It now doesn't matter if the drag was accepted or rejected by the target, if the dragged tab is in no-mans-land, it should go back to where it started from (hopefully!)

message.raw:
Fixed inmain_later needing an extra argument after the changes inplemented in changeset:65d006d40bf3

If you wish to not have exceptions raised in the main thread when calling inmain_later, either use the function decorator, or call in_main_later (note the extra underscore in between 'in' and 'main'. Also note that you must specifically import the new in_main_later function using `from qtutils.invoke_in_main import in_main_later`. This is because I don't want people accidentally using the wrong one due to their similar names)

Perhaps a better naming scheme will be developed one day!

Perhaps a better naming scheme will be developed one day!

values.message:
Fixed inmain_later needing an extra argument after the changes inplemented in changeset:65d006d40bf3

If you wish to not have exceptions raised in the main thread when calling inmain_later, either use the function decorator, or call in_main_later (note the extra underscore in between 'in' and 'main'. Also note that you must specifically import the new in_main_later function using `from qtutils.invoke_in_main import in_main_later`. This is because I don't want people accidentally using the wrong one due to their similar names)

Perhaps a better naming scheme will be developed one day!

message.raw:
Modified invoke_in_main to not "leak" memory

I put "leak" in quotes because it is yet unclear whether it actually does leak memory. What we do know is that the memory usage of a program using the in_main function does grow, but periodically it drops significantly. Longer testing must be done before we can tell whether we actually have a memory leak.

However, I have discovered that the Qt documentation states that an event passed to QCoreApplication.postEvent() should not be accessed after it is posted. We were accessing it to wait for the event to be processed. When we don't access it after calling QCoreApplication.postEvent() (and instead pass in a queue at event instantiation, which we then wait on), the memory usage does not grow nearly as rapidly and from preliminary observations, oscialltes around an average usage.

Further testing will ensue.

message.raw:
A fix to ensure that exceptions do not pass silently

functions delegated to the main thread with inmain_later now will raise exceptions
in the main thread if wait() has not been called on their events
(ie if no thread is listening on the result, and therefore no thread will otherwise raise the exception).

message.raw:
Rewrote the UiLoader class to be far better than the code I found on the internet

You can now promote widgets at runtime!
It is now much more general, and can apply to widgets beyond just the toplevel widget

As such there is now no trace of the code from the internet, so I'm relicensing this under the two-clause BSD as the rest of our work is.

message.raw:
Added some code (that I got from the internet, it is licensed under the MIT license) that modifies the behaviour of the QUiLoader

This code allows you to create the "QMainWindow" in Qt Designer, but override the QMainWindow class with your own when the UI is instantiated. This means you can subclass QMainWindow and override functions like closeEvent, while still designing the window in Qt Designer. See the BLACSWindow class in pythonlib/BLACS/main.pyw for an example implementation
